class="flyout-item"><a href="https://www.ajc.com/sports/atlanta-dream-headlines/" target="_self">Atlanta Dream</a></li><li class="flyout-item"><a href="https://www.ajc.com/sports/high-school/" target="_self">High School Sports</a></li><li class="flyout-item"><a href="https://www.ajc.com/sports/in-the-game/" target="_self">In The Game with Harrah&#x27;s</a></li><li class="flyout-item"><a href="https://www.ajc.com/sports/state-sports/" target="_self">State Sports Report</a></li><li class="flyout-item"><a href="http://ajc.stats.com/" target="_self">Scores and stats</a></li><li class="flyout-item"><a href="https://www.ajc.com/sports/sports-podcasts/KLEBP2SLOBEP3D2ATYUX44X3UU/" target="_self">AJC Sports Podcasts</a></li></ul></div></div></li></div><li class="nav-login nav-items "></li></div></div><div class="c-comments "><div class="close">X</div><div class="fb-comments" data-href="https://ajc.com/news/coronavirus/months-into-pandemic-ppe-shortage-persists/6OMYNYLDV5GJ5EBEMOSPWEC6MA/" data-width="100%" data-numposts="100"></div></div></div><div class="sticky-padding "></div></header></div><main class="c-articleContent"><header class="b-margin-bottom-d30-m20"><div class="c-header"><div class="article-headline-component b-margin-bottom-d30-m20 with-image"><div class="headline"><div class="headline-body"><h1 class="headline-text ">Months into pandemic, PPE shortage persists</h1></div></div><div class="c-image-component "><div class="image-component-image "><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><img src="/pf/resources/logos/AJC/placeholder.svg?d=107" style="width:100%"/></div><div class="c-caption " id="captionID-25928656" on="tap:captionID-25928656.toggleClass(class=&#x27;is-active&#x27;)" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="photo-caption-btn"><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div></div><div class="photo-caption"><div class="photo-caption-text">Irm Diorio, right, director of Decatur Makers, William Strika, left, executive director of Roswell Firelabs and Skyler Holobach, center, co-founder of Atlanta Shield Makers, put together face shields at Roswell Firelabs in Roswell. (Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com)</div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div></div></div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div></div></div><div style="display:flex;justify-content:center;flex-wrap:wrap" class="c-label-wrapper b-pageContainer b-margin-bottom-d15-m10"><a class="section-label section-label-link" href="/news/coronavirus">Coronavirus</a><span class="article-timestamp"> | Oct 7, 2020</span></div><div class="b-flexRow b-flexCenter b-pageContainer"><div class="byline b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><span>By <a href="/staff/helena-oliviero/">Helena Oliviero</a> - The Atlanta Journal-Constitution</span><span><a href="/staff/ariel-hart/">Ariel Hart</a> - The Atlanta Journal-Constitution</span></div></div><div class="b-flexRow b-flexCenter b-margin-bottom-d15-m10 b-pageContainer"></div></header><article><div class="c-hp01-mp01"></div><div class="c-articleBodyContainer"><div class="c-section\n          full-width b-clear-both\n          b-margin-bottom-d40-m20\n          "><div class="c-contentElements"><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Back in March as the pandemic took hold, Atlanta pediatrician Joy Maxey\xe2\x80\x99s two-year supply of high-filtering N95s masks was gone in weeks. Other <a href="https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional/preparing-for-surge-hospitals-limit-visitors-reschedule-surgeries/OqnPmLZhmMhwCu5jQ6JoBK/" target="_blank">critically needed equipment</a> was quickly depleted, too. She couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just pick up the phone and order more; her regular vendors didn\xe2\x80\x99t have it. She had to spend hours daily trying to find the precious gear.</p></div></div><div class="c-section\n          \n          b-margin-bottom-d40-m20\n          "><div class="c-contentElements"><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Now, seven months after Georgia confirmed its first coronavirus cases, Dr. Maxey is still spending triple the time she used to getting her office enough protective equipment.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Nationwide, that desperate <a href="https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional/still-strapped-for-resources-rural-hospitals-wary-opening/nl0BZR3foIoSwStdYJSyUL/" target="_blank">shortage of personal protective equipment</a> has ebbed some, and the headlines have faded. But the shortage isn\xe2\x80\x99t over. Health care providers from hospitals to doctors\' offices to nursing homes are still having to search for PPE and ration its use.</p></div></div><div class="story-nativo_placeholder--moap b-clear-both"></div><div class="c-section\n          \n          b-margin-bottom-d40-m20\n          "><div class="c-contentElements"><div class="c-image-component b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><div class="image-component-image "><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><img src="/pf/resources/logos/AJC/placeholder.svg?d=107" style="width:100%"/></div><div class="c-caption " id="captionID-46445257" on="tap:captionID-46445257.toggleClass(class=&#x27;is-active&#x27;)" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="photo-caption-btn"><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div></div><div class="photo-caption"><div class="photo-caption-text">10/6/2020 - Roswell, Georgia - Irm Diorio (left), director of Decatur Makers, Skyler Holobach (center), co-founder of Atlanta Shield Makers and William Strika (right), executive director of Roswell Firelabs, pose with face shields they created at Roswell Firelabs in Roswell, Tuesday, October 6, 2020. (Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com)</div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div></div></div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div><section class="borders b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><span class="prefix">Explore</span><a class="link" href="https://www.ajc.com/news/coronavirus/" target="_self">Complete coverage of COVID-19 in Georgia</a></section><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">For some, the initial fear and panic over the shortages has yielded to a drudging routine. Grady Memorial Hospital has a sterile room in its basement now devoted to manufacturing extra disinfecting wipes. A Stockbridge-based ambulance company has given an employee the full-time job of managing PPE. Nurses and doctors are still re-using masks that were designed to be used once and tossed away. Maxey has suspended plans for implementing an upgrade in her practice\xe2\x80\x99s patient communications, because she needs to spend her time instead sourcing PPE.</p></div></div><div class="c-section"><div class="story-interscroller__placeholder full-width c-clear-both c-contentElements"></div></div><div class="c-section\n          \n          b-margin-bottom-d40-m20\n          "><div class="c-contentElements"><p class="story-subscription__placeholder subscription-promo b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"></p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">In some places, the situation is ominous. According to recent federal data, 34 Georgia nursing homes reported they lacked a one-week supply of N95 masks. Fourteen nursing homes reported they lacked a one-week supply of gowns and 13 reported they lacked a one-week supply of gloves. Some of the nursing homes with the worst outbreaks are among those reporting shortages.</p><div class="c-image-component b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><div class="image-component-image "><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><img src="/pf/resources/logos/AJC/placeholder.svg?d=107" style="width:100%"/></div><div class="c-caption " id="captionID-81283339" on="tap:captionID-81283339.toggleClass(class=&#x27;is-active&#x27;)" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="photo-caption-btn"><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div></div><div class="photo-caption"><div class="photo-caption-text">William Strika, executive director of Roswell Firelabs, pieces together a face shield at Roswell Firelabs in Roswell. (Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com)</div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div></div></div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">All this, as flu season looms, with no one sure whether it will compound the epidemic.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">So medical workers like Maxey keep at it. They have no other choice, she said.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a time when our patients really need us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maxey, who<b> </b>is the owner of the small pediatric practice in Buckhead and<b> </b>serves as the office administrator. "This is where the rubber meets the road.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><b>Still not normal</b></p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Early in the pandemic, nursing homes in Georgia bought dust masks from tractor supply companies. They bought raincoats to use as makeshift hospital gowns. Paramedics snatched up painter masks at hardware stores. <a href="https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional/georgia-doctors-plan-for-wrenching-choices-amid-slim-ventilator-supply/wQsxpHBZ4NADgosPKG182N/" target="_blank">Hospitals drew up policies for who should get a ventilator</a> if two patients needed one and only one was left.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">That was spring and early summer. The U.S. solved the ventilator problem: President Trump in April invoked federal emergency law to help manufacturers get materials to ramp up production of the machines. Hospitals now report having more than enough.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">But the Government Accountability Office last month reported that PPE shortages persist nationwide and said the Department of Health and Human Services and FEMA should develop specific plans to help mitigate the supply gaps.</p><div class="c-image-component b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><div class="image-component-image "><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><img src="/pf/resources/logos/AJC/placeholder.svg?d=107" style="width:100%"/></div><div class="c-caption " id="captionID-42997706" on="tap:captionID-42997706.toggleClass(class=&#x27;is-active&#x27;)" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="photo-caption-btn"><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div></div><div class="photo-caption"><div class="photo-caption-text">An employee monitors latex gloves on hand-shaped molds moving along an automated production line at a Top Glove Corp. factory in Setia Alam, Malaysia, in this undated photo. (Samsul Said / Bloomberg)</div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Bloomberg</p></div></div></div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Bloomberg</p></div><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">GAO also noted that the Trump Administration pulled $6 billion from the $16.7 billion originally allocated to the Strategic National Stockpile to replenish stocks of PPE, ventilators and testing supplies, to use the money for its vaccine push.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Dr. Susan R. Bailey, president of the American Medical Association, said it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to believe the country is still dealing with some of the same PPE shortfalls experienced during the pandemic\xe2\x80\x99s early weeks. The reasons, she said, are \xe2\x80\x9cpainful and plentiful.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Health workers\' need for new PPE is continuous and can\xe2\x80\x99t be satisfied with a one-time bump in supply. And there\xe2\x80\x99s no centralized U.S. buyer for small users like Maxey. She still competes not only with other Georgia health care businesses but with people across the globe. Supplies are usually made overseas, making it tougher to find suppliers and easier for suppliers to play buyers off against one another.</p><section class="borders b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><span class="prefix">Explore</span><a class="link" href="https://www.ajc.com/news/coronavirus-georgia-hospitals/" target="_self">How hospitals are dealing with the coronavirus pandemic</a></section><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Big buyers, like hospital systems, have stockpiled. Grady has opened up new warehouse spaces off campus.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Maxey, a small buyer with little leverage, scours the market.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Sometimes her suppliers run out. It can change week to week. For about 90 minutes each week, she reaches out to vast contacts amassed over her 35-year-career. She gets on the Amazon Business website. Sometimes suppliers there are out of stock, too, so she tries again, and again. If she hits a score, she must research any new sources to make sure they are legitimate.</p><div class="blockquote b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a time when our patients really need us. This is where the rubber meets the road.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><div class="blockquote-citation">- <!-- -->Joy Maxey, Atlanta pediatrician</div></div><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Maxey estimates she\xe2\x80\x99ll spend $20,000 more on PPE this year. That\xe2\x80\x99s partly because she is using so much more, masking up for every patient in case one might be infected. And it\xe2\x80\x99s partly because the cost of products has risen, sometimes almost overnight.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Before the pandemic, a box of exam gloves cost $97. Now, that box costs $120, or even $140. A canister of disinfecting wipes, which used to cost $11, now costs $50 to $75.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">According to data from Premier, a health care group purchasing organization which works with about 4,100 U.S. hospitals and about 200,000 other providers and organizations, during a typical year, U.S. health systems buy about 25 million N95 masks. Demand this year will exceed 300 million N95 masks, Premier told the AJC.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">FEMA has said that the supply of N95 respirators for medical use is not expected to catch up with demand until January.</p><section class="borders b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><span class="prefix">Explore</span><a class="link" href="https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional/georgia-doctors-plan-for-wrenching-choices-amid-slim-ventilator-supply/wQsxpHBZ4NADgosPKG182N/" target="_self">From April: Georgia doctors plan for wrenching choices amid slim ventilator supply</a></section><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><a href="https://getusppe.org/data/">Get Us PPE</a>, a nonprofit group that connects health providers to available medical gear, said that pleas from Georgia for its extraordinary help had decreased dramatically since the early months of the pandemic \xe2\x80\x94but has not stopped. Earlier in the pandemic, more than half of the requests came from hospitals. But last month, all the requests came from non-hospital facilities, including nursing homes, home health agencies and homeless shelters.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Georgia nursing homes\' and personal care homes\' level of PPE use is 20 times greater than what it was before the pandemic, said Tony Marshall, president and CEO of the Georgia Health Care Association. He knows of no nursing home that has actually run out in recent weeks. But homes are still facing dwindling supplies, backorders and price hikes.</p><div class="c-image-component b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><div class="image-component-image "><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><img src="/pf/resources/logos/AJC/placeholder.svg?d=107" style="width:100%"/></div><div class="c-caption " id="captionID-62253976" on="tap:captionID-62253976.toggleClass(class=&#x27;is-active&#x27;)" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="photo-caption-btn"><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div></div><div class="photo-caption"><div class="photo-caption-text">In this file photo, Adriana Sarti, an assistant at Windy Hill Dentistry, uses a disinfectant wipe to sanitize the treatment room after a patient left. While dentists for decades have worn masks and gloves when treating patients, the coronavirus pandemic has led to even stricter infection-control measures. (Hyosub Shin / Hyosub.Shin@ajc.com)</div><p class="photo-credit-text"></p></div></div></div><p class="photo-credit-text"></p></div><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><b>Coming soon: The flu, schools opening, people voting</b></p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Early in the pandemic, <a href="https://atlantabeatscovid.com/" target="_blank">Atlanta Beats Covid (ABC), a group of Atlanta makers who banded together</a> to create PPE, worked to address desperate shortages at hospitals. Volunteer Skyler Holobach, who works full-time at Salesforce, spent seven hours every evening pouring and molding plastic in a spare bedroom to make face shields. That went on for months.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">In recent weeks, requests for shields have slowed and are now coming outside health care settings, including schools and polling places. So volunteers with ABC are planning to sunset the group by Nov. 1. But many of the volunteers will continue to make needed supplies, including the Maker Station Marietta, which plans to make isolation gowns.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">\xe2\x80\x9cWe will see how things go, and we will be ready to go and be able to quickly ramp things back up if need be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Holobach, who is now sewing and donating masks.</p><div class="c-image-component b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><div class="image-component-image "><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><img src="/pf/resources/logos/AJC/placeholder.svg?d=107" style="width:100%"/></div><div class="c-caption " id="captionID-14869845" on="tap:captionID-14869845.toggleClass(class=&#x27;is-active&#x27;)" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="photo-caption-btn"><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div><div class="fill-line"></div><div class="fill-line fill-line-long"></div></div><div class="photo-caption"><div class="photo-caption-text">Skyler Holobach, co-founder of Atlanta Shield Makers, pieces together a face shield at Roswell Firelabs in Roswell. (Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com)</div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div></div></div><p class="photo-credit-text">Credit: Alyssa Pointer / Alyssa.Pointer@ajc.com</p></div><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Hospital administrators in charge of PPE supplies also are watching and waiting to see what unfolds as flu season begins, cold weather drives people into enclosed spaces and holidays tempt people to gather.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">\xe2\x80\x9cThe sense of fear is I think abated," said Dr. Robert Jansen, chief medical officer of Grady. \xe2\x80\x9cI think the only anxiety that currently remains is still not knowing what the next few months is going to bring.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">Jansen hopes people wear masks and follow protective practices. He also hopes the supply system improves.</p><p class="story-text b-margin-bottom-d40-m20">\xe2\x80\x9cWe just want there to be adequate manufacturing so we\xe2\x80\x99re not dependent on overseas," Jansen said. "The whole world is wrestling with the same problem. We need PPE, they need PPE.\xe2\x80\x9d</p><p class="c-connext hyperlocal_promo b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"></p><p class="c-connext eos-msg__nolog-or-nosub b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"></p></div></div><div class="c-section full-width b-clear-both"><div class="c-relatedList b-margin-bottom-d40-m20"><h1 class="title">In Other News</h1><div class="c-homeListContainer two-columns left-photo-display-class"></div></div></div><div class="c-section"><div id="taboola-ajc-custom-feed" class="b-clear-both"></div></div><div class="taboola-split"><div If each person gets one person sick, the epidemic neither grows nor shrinks. Less than one means each person infects, on average, fewer than one person, so the epidemic shrinks. If Rt is larger than one, the epidemic grows. As Rt moves farther from 1, the epidemic shrinks or grows more rapidly."},{"_id":"N7ZJTIZNZ5BRNNFRGBWFVZKJ5Y","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"_id":1594919557285,"inline_comments":[]},"content":"The AJC calculated and compared several independent methods to estimate a value for Rt in Georgia. While the results from all were very similar, we\'re displaying a method designed by the Imperial College of London that uses epidemic curves to produce Rt estimates. The college\'s method is unrelated to its COVID-19 estimates."},{"_id":"F4P4RJEDAZFMZNDSUFMQO2FI4Q","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"_id":1594919557286,"inline_comments":[]},"content":"As with other data presented on this dashboard, Rt values lag because of testing lags."},{"_id":"GUENHN5DEBDIHBRIOUKW5VNBFQ","type":"raw_html","additional_properties":{"id":"U76524063418oDE","comments":[],"_id":1594919557287},"content":"<PymLoader url=\\"https://ajcnewsapps.s3.amazonaws.com/2020/covid-rt/index.html\\" id=\\"rt-chart-container\\" />\\n"},{"_id":"YVMXODZ44NFK5IKJ36UZMUYTSY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"_id":1594919557288,"inline_comments":[]},"content":"Do you have more questions? The CCD team also handles regional, national and international news with a focus on how it affects Georgians. Barak, who has covered everyone from Prince Charles to Timothy Leary, has been a journalist for more than 30 years. Before joining the AJC, Barak worked as the executive digital producer for the NBC affiliate in Milwaukee. He also had a stint at the Chicago Tribune. He was selected as Illinois\' best headline writer in 2014 by The Associated Press in its annual contest. When he is not working, Barak likes to spend time with his family and his dog. His wife, Pam, has worked for the American Cancer Society and hospitals during her career. They have three grown children: Brandon, the director of player development for Vanderbilt\'s College World Series champion baseball team; Kaley, who teaches students with special needs in a Phoenix suburb; and Matthew, a Class of 2020 Georgetown University graduate who majored in government/political science. The CCD team also handles regional, national and international news with a focus on how it affects Georgians. Barak, who has covered everyone from Prince Charles to Timothy Leary, has been a journalist for more than 30 years. Before joining the AJC, Barak worked as the executive digital producer for the NBC affiliate in Milwaukee. He also had a stint at the Chicago Tribune. He was selected as Illinois\' best headline writer in 2014 by The Associated Press in its annual contest. When he is not working, Barak likes to spend time with his family and his dog. His wife, Pam, has worked for the American Cancer Society and hospitals during her career. They have three grown children: Brandon, the director of player development for Vanderbilt\'s College World Series champion baseball team; Kaley, who teaches students with special needs in a Phoenix suburb; and Matthew, a Class of 2020 Georgetown University graduate who majored in government/political science. Barak, who has covered everyone from Prince Charles to Timothy Leary, has been a journalist for more than 30 years. Before joining the AJC, Barak worked as the executive digital producer for the NBC affiliate in Milwaukee. He also had a stint at the Chicago Tribune. He was selected as Illinois\' best headline writer in 2014 by The Associated Press in its annual contest. When he is not working, Barak likes to spend time with his family and his dog. His wife, Pam, has worked for the American Cancer Society and hospitals during her career. They have three grown children: Brandon, the director of player development for Vanderbilt\'s College World Series champion baseball team; Kaley, who teaches students with special needs in a Phoenix suburb; and Matthew, a Class of 2020 Georgetown University graduate who majored in government/political science. His work at the newspaper over the past decade has rooted out corruption and abuse, leading to changes in state law and federal investigations. \\nEdwards previously worked at daily newspapers in Lynchburg, Va., and Augusta, Ga., and served time as an embedded reporter during the invasion of Iraq. are particularly advantageous for face coverings and can facilitate their use by the general public,\xe2\x80\x9d the researchers wrote in their study, <a href=\\"https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0239531\\" target=_blank>published recently in the journal Plos One</a>."},{"_id":"YVO3CQCHL5FPTHXMN5NLHKKEGQ","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1601049081485},"content":"Although cotton fabric is breathable, it absorbs water."},{"_id":"M2PIIJRPZNAJXCR4UMNTXL3NIE","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1601049081486},"content":"\xe2\x80\x9cWe found that cotton materials are hydrophilic, and readily allow droplets to rapidly penetrate and saturate the fabric like a sponge,\xe2\x80\x9d the researchers wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cTherefore, face coverings made out of these materials may quickly become reservoirs of virus and act as conduits for viral transmission when worn, even after a short time.\xe2\x80\x9d"},{"_id":"G7FTF4UXL5AOXDQ2AUEVTDXJFE","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1601049081487},"content":"Polyester not only absorbed water, but also was difficult to breathe in."},{"_id":"EAUW7Z2BVNCTXMLXSY5DGLHPTM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1601049081488},"content":"\xe2\x80\x9cFace coverings made out of polyester face these same limitations, as we found it to be hydrophilic like cotton,\xe2\x80\x9d the researchers concluded. \xe2\x80\x9cTherefore, cloth and polyester face coverings appear to be more suitable for brief, one-time use.\xe2\x80\x9d"},{"_id":"UJBAANPJFJASZFDBBLUQ7LHBAY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1601049081489},"content":"In contrast, they wrote, can make it a more advantageous material for face coverings that are also thin, light, and \' is-loggedIn\' : \'\';\n          if (typeof(window.localStorage) !== \'undefined\') {\n            const connextLS = window.localStorage.getItem(\'connext_user_data_AJC_AJC_PROD_DEFAULT_PROD\');\n            if (connextLS) {\n              const loginEventName = \'loginEvent_complete\';\n              const loginEventToTrigger = !window[loginEventName] ? \'loginEvent_return-user\' : null;\n              const { CustomerRegistrationId } = JSON.parse(connextLS);\n              const userDataObj = {\n                \'userData\': {\n                  \'userActive\': \'logged in\',\n                  \'userProfileID\': CustomerRegistrationId\n                },\n                \'event\': loginEventToTrigger\n              };\n              dataLayer.push(userDataObj);\n            }\n          }\n        } else if (action === \'logged-out\') {\n          docBody.className = docBody.className.replace(/is-loggedIn/g, \'\').replace(/is-authenticated/g, \'\');\n          docBody.className += docBody.className.indexOf(\'is-loggedOut\') === -1 ? \' is-loggedOut\' : \'\';\n          const userDataObj = {\n            \'userData\': {\n              \'userActive\': \'not logged in\',\n              \'userProfileID\': null\n            }\n          };\n          dataLayer.push(userDataObj);\n        } else if (action === \'authenticated\' && docBody.className.indexOf(\'is-authenticated\') === -1) {\n          docBody.className += \' is-authenticated\';\n        }\n      };\n      const connextLogger = (message) => {\n        if (false || window.location.search.indexOf(\'connextDebug\') > -1) {\n          console.log(message);\n        }\n      };\n      window.addEventListener(\'connextLoggedIn\', () => {\n        toggleUserState(\'logged-in\');\n      });\n      window.addEventListener(\'connextLoggedOut\', () => {\n        toggleUserState(\'logged-out\');\n      });\n      window.addEventListener(\'connextIsSubscriber\', () => {\n        toggleUserState(\'authenticated\');\n      });\n      window.addEventListener(\'connextMeterLevelSet\', () => {\n        /*\n          workaround for APD-960, since binding to the logout button click isn\'t working (connext fires too quickly)\n          and connext actually double-fires the "onNotAuthorized" event.  So we set this property when connext first loads\n          and then we delete it - if it hasn\'t been already - once the meter level is set (one of the later processes for connext)\n        */\n        if (typeof window.connextInitialLoadComplete !== \'undefined\') {\n          delete window.connextInitialLoadComplete;\n        } else {\n          const userState = Connext.Storage.GetUserState() || \'\';\n          if (userState.toLowerCase() === \'logged out\') {\n            dataLayer.push({\'event\': \'loginEvent_logout\'});\n          }\n        }\n      });\n      doc.addEventListener(\'DOMContentLoaded\', () => {\n        const connextLoaded = new Event(\'connextLoaded\');\n        const connextMeterLevelSet = new Event(\'connextMeterLevelSet\');\n        const connextLoggedIn = new Event(\'connextLoggedIn\');\n        const connextLoggedOut = new Event(\'connextLoggedOut\');\n        const connextIsSubscriber = new Event(\'connextIsSubscriber\');\n        Promise.resolve(window.MG2Loader.init({\n          plugins: [\n            {\n              name: \'FP\',\n              initOptions: {\n                version: \'ajc\' || \'1.0\',\n \'ajc\',\n                collectors: [\'connext\'],\n                tagManager: \'GTM\',\n                containerId: \'GTM-W3VLHBK\',\n              },\n            },\n            {\n              name: \'NXT\',\n              initOptions: {\n                clientCode: \'ajc\',\n                environment: \'prod\',\n                siteCode: \'AJC\',\n                configCode: \'AJC_PROD_DEFAULT\',\n                debug: false,\n                silentmode: false,\n                publicEventHandlers: {\n                  onActionClosed: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onActionClosed\', e); },\n                  onActionShown: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onActionShown\', e); },\n                  onButtonClick: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onButtonClick\', e); },\n                  onCampaignFound: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onCampaignFound\', e); },\n                  onConversationDetermined: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onConversationDetermined\', e); },\n                  onCriticalError: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onCriticalError\', e); },\n                  onDebugNote: (e) => { connextLogger(\'>> onDebugNote\', e); },\n                  onInit: (e) => {\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onInit\', e);\n                    window.connextInitialLoadComplete = true;\n                    window.dispatchEvent(connextLoaded);\n                  },\n                  onLoggedIn: (e) => {\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onLoggedIn\', e);\n                    window.dispatchEvent(connextLoggedIn);\n                  },\n                  onNotAuthorized: (e) => {\n                    // this event fires on every Engage loading if user is logged out\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onNotAuthorized\', e);\n                    window.dispatchEvent(connextLoggedOut);\n                  },\n                  onMeterLevelSet: (e) => {\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onMeterLevelSet\', e);\n                    window.dispatchEvent(connextMeterLevelSet);\n                  },\n                  onAuthorized: (e) => {\n                    // this event fires on every Engage loading if user is logged in but doesn\'t have access to this product\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onAuthorized\', e);\n                  },\n                  onHasNoActiveSubscription: (e) => {\n                    // this event fires on every Engage loading if user is logged in but subscription is stopped or inactive\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onHasNoActiveSubscription\', e);\n                  },\n                  onHasAccessNotEntitled: (e) => {\n                    // this event fires on every Engage loading if user is logged in\n                    // and doesn\'t have access to this product but has access to another one\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onHasAccessNotEntitled\', e);\n                  },\n                  onHasAccess: (e) => {\n                    // this event fires on every Engage loading if user is subscriber\n                    connextLogger(\'>> onHasAccess\', e);\n                    window.dispatchEvent(connextIsSubscriber);\n                  },\n                },\n              },\n            },\n          ],\n        }));\n      });</script><div id="fb-root"></div><script async="" defer="" crossorigin="anonymous"
